Award.AwardTitle: MUMADE Marymount University Mobile Apps Development for Everyone

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses mobile app development in required, inquiry-based general education courses to increase the number of non-STEM and undeclared major students who see technology as a career objective. Through this exposure as technology creators rather than just as consumers, it is hoped that students will develop an interest in pursuing more STEM courses and majors. The project is developing a series of mobile app courses and is also training faculty on how to include these concepts into a number of other general education courses. While university freshmen, transfer students, and students at risk of leaving the university are the primary audience for the courses, rising junior and senior students at local high schools as well as students at Northern Virginia Community College have access to the mobile app development courses through Marymount's summer institute.

A particular focus and strength of the project is formal assessment of student: learning gains, interest in technology, confidence with technology, and attention to increases in the number of STEM majors at the university after introduction of the mobile app development courses and concepts. The outcomes of this research could contribute to a foundation for understanding the degree to which the engagement with mobile app development affects students' interest, persistence, and learning gains in STEM, computing, and IT majors and careers. In addition to faculty training workshops, the project's progress and results are available through the project website and at local, regional, and national conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop a "mobile application (app) development" curriculum (MUMADE) and used it as a vehicle to prepare non-STEM students with substantial STEM competencies and to inspire them to participate in the computing field, in college and later as a career. In order to broaden underrepresented groups participation in the STEM field, special attention was to be paid to women, minorities, Veterans, and students with barriers to learning. Our ultimate goal was to research, develop, and recommend ways to improve the recruiting of students into the technology field, even if they did not see themselves as "technologists". The mobile apps course (MUMADE) was essentially incorporated into the Marymount DISCOVER program and offered to undergraduate students at Marymount University. In addition, the course was taught to middle and high schools students in the past three summers as part of Marymount's existing summer institute event.

The DISCOVER program, as the foundation for this project, has a required syllabus and faculty members develop the content for their own designated subject area. Incoming freshmen students take a three-credit first year seminar, DSC 101, and entering transfer students take DSC 201, a one-credit course, in which they are exposed to inquiry learning and begin to develop or refine research skills. Through the DISCOVER program students are exposed to Marymount University expectations, events, and services. The main theme of the MUMADE courses is to teach students computational thinking and a confidence in their technology creation skills through creating "apps" for Android devices using MIT’s App Inventor. It also provides an opportunity for students to use a required inquiry course (DISCOVER) in Marymount’s general education program to explore the development of mobile apps (a common phenomenon in their young lives). The demographics data shows that almost 40% of the students taking DSC courses are non-IT/CS students, including various majors such as fashion merchandising, nursing, education, business, biology, and fashion design.

In addition to running MUMADE courses for college students, three summer technology camps were held in 2014, 2015, and 2016 with a specific focus on cultivating and fostering the students (age of 13-17 year-old) to design and create the their OWN mobile apps. There was an average of 20 students in each annual camp, and about 37% of them were female. The program was taught by a female IT faculty and 50% of student workers and volunteers are female. This five-day session program culminated with very successful Mobile App Expo held on the last afternoon of the Summer Institute. This Expo allowed students, individually or in teams, to create and display their mobile apps (prototype) to their classmates, IT students from Marymount, faculty, family, school administrators, and business professionals. The students were expected to demonstrate the problem they were trying to solve with the mobile app and their computational thinking that resulted in the app itself. They demonstrated their app to the audiences and communicated their methodology in discussions with the audience, as there was no formal presentation.  This Expo and whole summer camp received many interests and raves from parents, faculty members from Marymount.

This grant has exposed a wide variety of general education students to mobile app development in a variety of settings to raise the level of awareness and appreciation of technology as well as “what is behind the scenes of technology” (connecting computing). The techniques we have used to reach these students include direct teaching in general education courses for initial freshman and transfer students; direct teaching for students who had some barriers to learning and who failed the initial Discover course with another topic; and as taught as part of a summer school institute for high school students.  

With a relatively high percentage of female participants in the summer institute and the Discover courses, we believe that we have attracted more females into the technology field through these activities that combine creativity with computational thinking.

Further, we have actively reached out to the local high school (such as Arlington and Fairfax), trained high school teachers in the App Inventor tools and methodology, and collaborated with them to expose high school students to the academic side of a technology education. Early exposure to these fundamental elements of computational thinking will lead students to a better sense of their own interests in the technology field or beyond. We realize that this is an effective approach as for increasing the broader impact on the middle- and high- student population

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2016
Modified by: Michelle Liu
